description: Over 80% of computers run Microsoft Operating systems [reference]. As a result, the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate (MCSA) is one of the first steps for those seeking to start a technical career. The MCSA: Windows 7 covers topics that are “must know” for anyone responsible for deploying, maintaining and supporting Windows desktops in a corporate or enterprise environment. Most people know how to use Windows in a home environment. However, there are many features under the hood that are designed for environments with a large quantity of computers. The MCSA dives in to those and gives the learner a whole new toolbox for ensuring their computing environment is functional and stable.

01:19:18,650 --> 01:19:22,950

01:19:26,610 --> 01:19:31,461

1410
01:19:31,461 --> 01:19:34,837

01:19:34,837 --> 01:19:38,054

01:19:43,975 --> 01:19:47,663

01:21:07,500 --> 01:21:12,050

01:21:12,050 --> 01:21:18,070

1435
01:21:18,070 --> 01:21:23,070

1436
01:21:23,070 --> 01:21:24,290

01:21:24,290 --> 01:21:27,180

01:21:27,180 --> 01:21:30,140

01:21:31,780 --> 01:21:33,670

01:21:42,330 --> 01:21:47,250

01:21:47,250 --> 01:21:49,980

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Don tackle the most common user management tasks within a Windows 7. They demonstrate and discuss how to configure shared resources such as printers and folders. They also protect data through encrypting files and using NTFS permissions. They discuss what happens with permissions when moving and copying files.

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Wes take a look at monitoring Windows 7 through various tools included by default in a typical Windows installation. topics.title: Monitoring and maintaining systems that run Windows 7

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Ronnie talk about the importance of backups for Windows 7 and the built options available. They show the use of system restore points and restoring previous versions of files as well.
episodes.title: Backup and Recovery Options
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,295 --> 00:00:37,546
All right, welcome back to another
fantastic episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:37,546 --> 00:00:41,270
I am Nathan Copeland
here with Ronnie Wong.

4
00:00:41,270 --> 00:00:42,330
>> How's it going Nate.

5
00:00:42,330 --> 00:00:43,820
>> Pretty good, Ronnie.

6
00:00:43,820 --> 00:00:45,180
>> Excited that it's Friday and

7
00:00:45,180 --> 00:00:50,732
that we are completing our
Windows 7 episodes pretty soon?

8
00:00:50,732 --> 00:00:53,546
>> Yeah, there's the disk.

9
00:00:53,546 --> 00:00:55,400
Yes, it is Friday.

10
00:00:55,400 --> 00:00:58,160
We are winding down Windows 7.

11
00:00:58,160 --> 00:01:01,210
And so, down here at the end,

12
00:01:01,210 --> 00:01:06,520
we're gonna be talking about backup and
recovery options inside of Windows 7.

13
00:01:06,520 --> 00:01:07,940
And you know what?

14
00:01:07,940 --> 00:01:12,020
I did not have a chance to
pull up the objectives yet,

15
00:01:12,020 --> 00:01:15,290
but I'll get those guys
up here in a minute.

16
00:01:15,290 --> 00:01:19,870
So today, we'll be going over backup and
recovery options in Windows 7.

17
00:01:19,870 --> 00:01:23,431
We've got things like creating
a system recovery disk,

18
00:01:23,431 --> 00:01:27,297
setting up our backup schedules,
and good things like that.

19
00:01:27,297 --> 00:01:30,220
>> And a little bit of file
recovery here at the end.

20
00:01:30,220 --> 00:01:32,880
So this episode is not super intensive.

21
00:01:32,880 --> 00:01:37,770
If you spent any time in working with
the idea of WIndows operating systems,

22
00:01:37,770 --> 00:01:41,070
you've got to understand that it's
not the operating system itself that

23
00:01:41,070 --> 00:01:43,160
everything has to come together on, right?

24
00:01:43,160 --> 00:01:46,060
We have to ensure that we can
continue to actually keep

25
00:01:46,060 --> 00:01:47,760
all of our files up and running.

26
00:01:47,760 --> 00:01:50,980
And so that means the operating
system of course depends on hardware.

27
00:01:50,980 --> 00:01:54,650
And that means you can't really depend
on it for too long a lot of times here.

28
00:01:54,650 --> 00:01:58,740
And so, it means that we have to actually
have some ability to recover those files

29
00:01:58,740 --> 00:02:02,070
in case something happens to the machine
or the operating system itself.

30
00:02:02,070 --> 00:02:04,530
One of the best ways to do that of course,

31
00:02:04,530 --> 00:02:06,890
is by taking a look at
the idea of backups.

32
00:02:06,890 --> 00:02:10,210
Backups are one of the most important
aspects of what we can do in terms

33
00:02:10,210 --> 00:02:11,310
of computing.

34
00:02:11,310 --> 00:02:14,520
Now, I know that there's a lot of people
that go Ronnie I've never backed up my

35
00:02:14,520 --> 00:02:16,770
computer in six years.

36
00:02:16,770 --> 00:02:18,980
Nate, when was the last time you
ran a backup on your computer?

37
00:02:20,150 --> 00:02:22,790
>> It would have to be maybe a month ago.

38
00:02:22,790 --> 00:02:23,820
>> A month ago? That's- >> A month ago.

39
00:02:23,820 --> 00:02:24,490
>> That's pretty good.

40
00:02:24,490 --> 00:02:26,450
Yeah, mine was about two months ago here.

41
00:02:26,450 --> 00:02:29,650
And remember that our computer
systems have changed over time.

42
00:02:29,650 --> 00:02:34,120
And now if Nate for one reason or
another ends up losing his data,

43
00:02:34,120 --> 00:02:37,220
in that time that he actually,
since he last backed up.

44
00:02:37,220 --> 00:02:38,490
Well, now we've got an issue.

45
00:02:38,490 --> 00:02:40,150
He can't go back and recover it.

46
00:02:40,150 --> 00:02:42,910
And so, we want to make sure that you
understand how to use the tools inside of

47
00:02:42,910 --> 00:02:45,340
Windows 7 to go ahead and create a backup.

48
00:02:45,340 --> 00:02:47,770
And we'll take a look at some
of the options there as well.

49
00:02:47,770 --> 00:02:50,836
>> Yep, so Ronnie, before we get started,
let me ask you this.

50
00:02:50,836 --> 00:02:52,160
>> Yes.

51
00:02:52,160 --> 00:02:54,270
>> So you backed up two months ago.

52
00:02:54,270 --> 00:02:55,830
>> I did.
>> All right,

53
00:02:55,830 --> 00:03:01,200
have you ever lost a lot of data
that you have not had backed up?

54
00:03:01,200 --> 00:03:03,440
>> I have not lost a lot of
data that I've had backed

55
00:03:03,440 --> 00:03:03,980
up,
>> Okay.

56
00:03:03,980 --> 00:03:06,350
>> Except for
the very fact that I've misplaced stuff.

57
00:03:06,350 --> 00:03:06,911
>> All right, well, let me,
>> Yeah.

58
00:03:06,911 --> 00:03:08,895
[LAUGH]
>> Okay, instead of a lot of data have you

59
00:03:08,895 --> 00:03:11,503
ever lost any data that you
were unable to replace?

60
00:03:11,503 --> 00:03:13,128
>> Yes.

61
00:03:13,128 --> 00:03:14,255
Yes I have.

62
00:03:15,560 --> 00:03:18,050
By just simply misplacing the information.

63
00:03:18,050 --> 00:03:18,564
>> Oh, okay.
>> Yeah.

64
00:03:18,564 --> 00:03:20,158
>> Right?

65
00:03:20,158 --> 00:03:20,866
>> Yeah, true.

66
00:03:20,866 --> 00:03:22,086
[LAUGH]
>> Okay, all right.

67
00:03:22,086 --> 00:03:22,960
Well yeah, okay.

68
00:03:22,960 --> 00:03:24,020
Well I.

69
00:03:24,020 --> 00:03:25,180
>> Are wondering if I'm lying to you?

70
00:03:25,180 --> 00:03:25,860
>> Well no, no, no.

71
00:03:25,860 --> 00:03:27,450
I thought there was more to the story.

72
00:03:27,450 --> 00:03:31,628
>> And so just like yes, I haven't, okay.

73
00:03:31,628 --> 00:03:33,730
>> So,
you've never had a hard drive crash?

74
00:03:33,730 --> 00:03:38,140
You've never had, like, carrying something
and just dropped it and it broke?

75
00:03:38,140 --> 00:03:40,045
>> No, no.

76
00:03:40,045 --> 00:03:42,838
I've been one of those lucky people
that really haven't had a lot of

77
00:03:42,838 --> 00:03:44,260
failures like that.

78
00:03:44,260 --> 00:03:49,150
But what I have had again, is the idea
of me misplacing stuff, or moving from

79
00:03:49,150 --> 00:03:52,810
one computer system to another one,
and not remembering where I put stuff.

80
00:03:52,810 --> 00:03:54,430
So yeah, it does happen.

81
00:03:54,430 --> 00:03:56,961
>> I'll share a quick story with you.

82
00:03:56,961 --> 00:03:58,510
>> All right, sounds great.

83
00:03:58,510 --> 00:04:01,750
>> So I have this, I had this hard drive.

84
00:04:01,750 --> 00:04:04,490
And on the hard drive,
it was a terabyte drive, and

85
00:04:04,490 --> 00:04:08,000
it was chock full of
all these media files.

86
00:04:08,000 --> 00:04:14,150
Movies and TV shows and MP3s,
it had thousands upon thousands of MP3s.

87
00:04:14,150 --> 00:04:17,600
Everything was on this one drive and
that's all it had.

88
00:04:17,600 --> 00:04:22,140
There were no other backups or copies and
it's just music and media, right?

89
00:04:22,140 --> 00:04:25,310
Nothing terribly, irreplaceable.

90
00:04:25,310 --> 00:04:29,950
One day, I browsed to the hard drive,
and Windows did not recognize it.

91
00:04:29,950 --> 00:04:30,920
It was just nothing.

92
00:04:30,920 --> 00:04:33,050
Absolutely dead in the water.

93
00:04:33,050 --> 00:04:36,230
I pulled that drive out and
I stuck it another PC.

94
00:04:36,230 --> 00:04:40,190
I ran some recovery software on it.

95
00:04:40,190 --> 00:04:43,180
I could browse and
I could see the file structure and so

96
00:04:43,180 --> 00:04:45,310
it wasn't completely dead.

97
00:04:45,310 --> 00:04:47,198
I just couldn't get to it the normal way.

98
00:04:47,198 --> 00:04:52,480
I couldn't double-click on any songs and
play them back in Media Player.

99
00:04:52,480 --> 00:04:55,310
Well, so with this recovery software,

100
00:04:55,310 --> 00:05:00,290
I was able to recover just about
all the files from that disk.

101
00:05:00,290 --> 00:05:01,730
>> Wow, you must have been very happy.

102
00:05:02,990 --> 00:05:06,010
>> I was.
However, as it recovered everything,

103
00:05:06,010 --> 00:05:07,160
it created one folder.

104
00:05:07,160 --> 00:05:10,870
It was recovery and
then the date that it ran.

105
00:05:10,870 --> 00:05:16,336
And browsing into that
folder it was file00001.

106
00:05:16,336 --> 00:05:17,129
>> Renamed all your files.

107
00:05:17,129 --> 00:05:19,720
>> Below it file00002.

108
00:05:19,720 --> 00:05:24,280
It took everything, I mean there were
thousands upon thousands of files.

109
00:05:24,280 --> 00:05:27,960
And it gave them all generic names and
dumped them all into one folder.

110
00:05:27,960 --> 00:05:28,700
>> Nice.
[LAUGH]

111
00:05:28,700 --> 00:05:30,326
>> So I still have it so

112
00:05:30,326 --> 00:05:35,007
that folder is tucked away
because one day I might wanna

113
00:05:35,007 --> 00:05:39,296
listen to something that
I forgot a long time ago.

114
00:05:39,296 --> 00:05:40,253
>> [CROSSTALK] zero, zero, five.

115
00:05:40,253 --> 00:05:43,332
>> Yeah.

116
00:05:43,332 --> 00:05:47,670
I still consider it a loss,
there's like all the meta data for

117
00:05:47,670 --> 00:05:52,070
the all songs, MP3s, what album they were
on, the track, the artists, everything.

118
00:05:52,070 --> 00:05:56,310
Even all the movies with their,
anyhow, but yes, so

119
00:05:56,310 --> 00:06:01,530
if I had a backup of that folder, then
it would have saved a lot of heartache.

120
00:06:01,530 --> 00:06:05,080
And now today,
I use Windows storage spaces.

121
00:06:05,080 --> 00:06:07,580
I use storage spaces to
slave in a bunch of drives,

122
00:06:07,580 --> 00:06:11,990
I think there's five drives now that
it writes all the information onto.

123
00:06:11,990 --> 00:06:16,170
So if I lose one drive,
then everything's fine.

124
00:06:16,170 --> 00:06:19,150
>> Yeah.
>> I've since upgraded my stuff.

125
00:06:19,150 --> 00:06:20,160
>> Yeah, so remember that.

126
00:06:20,160 --> 00:06:21,780
What Nate is mentioning
here in storage spaces.

127
00:06:21,780 --> 00:06:23,650
You're not going to find
inside of Windows 7.

128
00:06:23,650 --> 00:06:27,880
What you are going to find though is
actually going to be the Windows Backup

129
00:06:27,880 --> 00:06:28,690
itself.

130
00:06:28,690 --> 00:06:32,100
So Nate, do you wanna take a look
at the idea of Windows Backup?

131
00:06:32,100 --> 00:06:32,760
>> All right yeah, sure.

132
00:06:32,760 --> 00:06:36,170
So Windows Backup, the bulk of what
we're gonna be going over today.

133
00:06:36,170 --> 00:06:39,150
And Ronnie, I did get up those objectives
>> Oh, excellent.

134
00:06:39,150 --> 00:06:42,910
>> I browsed to them, and so
today we'll be going over

135
00:06:42,910 --> 00:06:47,440
configuring a backup with recovery
disks and it's scheduling a backup.

136
00:06:47,440 --> 00:06:50,810
We'll be going over the recovery options,

137
00:06:50,810 --> 00:06:56,480
such as system restore points and
how to restore from these restore points.

138
00:06:56,480 --> 00:06:58,440
Rolling back a driver.

139
00:06:58,440 --> 00:07:03,280
And then file restore points and
previous versions of files, shadow copies.

140
00:07:04,700 --> 00:07:06,460
Restore user profiles.

141
00:07:06,460 --> 00:07:14,490
I know of two tools off the top of
my head that we can use to get that.

142
00:07:14,490 --> 00:07:15,900
Anyhow, there we go.

143
00:07:15,900 --> 00:07:16,930
>> All right, sounds good.

144
00:07:16,930 --> 00:07:20,090
>> So to jump back anything I'm
gonna just start from the beginning.

145
00:07:21,200 --> 00:07:26,980
So control panel all right, we'll go and
click on System and Security.

146
00:07:26,980 --> 00:07:31,570
And then in System and Security,
we'll go down do Backup and Restore.

147
00:07:33,490 --> 00:07:36,220
So here we go.
So now on this Windows 7 machine I haven't

148
00:07:36,220 --> 00:07:39,000
run any backups or any history like that.

149
00:07:39,000 --> 00:07:42,336
And so, there's not really a whole
lot to look at in this point.

150
00:07:42,336 --> 00:07:48,958
But the very first objective mentions
creating a system repair disk.

151
00:07:48,958 --> 00:07:53,865
Now to create a system repair disk, the
link is just over here on the left side.

152
00:07:53,865 --> 00:07:58,697
Now if we click on it,
it's going to give me a big fat error

153
00:07:58,697 --> 00:08:02,610
that it does not detect a DVD burner.

154
00:08:02,610 --> 00:08:04,890
So on this XPS there
are no optical drives,

155
00:08:04,890 --> 00:08:07,840
which is a trend I've been seeing lately.

156
00:08:07,840 --> 00:08:10,850
These machines,
they don't have any optical drives but

157
00:08:10,850 --> 00:08:16,590
if you want a system repair disk, you're
going to need a DVD burner of some kind.

158
00:08:16,590 --> 00:08:21,370
And so basically what this is is going
to make like a Windows PE type disk.

159
00:08:21,370 --> 00:08:24,060
A disk with some recovery tools on it.

160
00:08:24,060 --> 00:08:28,940
You can boot from this disk in case your
computer is just hosed to no end and

161
00:08:28,940 --> 00:08:33,690
booting off of this disk, it'll give you
options that you can run a system restore,

162
00:08:33,690 --> 00:08:41,790
you can load up a system image, a bit for
bit copy of Windows, things of that sort.

163
00:08:41,790 --> 00:08:43,400
So a good thing to have it.

164
00:08:43,400 --> 00:08:49,430
If you have a Windows installation DVD,
that will also work in this case.

165
00:08:49,430 --> 00:08:53,480
We will able to click through
the really cool wizard,

166
00:08:53,480 --> 00:08:55,220
if I move this out to the side.

167
00:08:56,230 --> 00:09:00,820
So what you do is put in a blank DVD or

168
00:09:00,820 --> 00:09:06,140
CD in your optical drive and
it will pop up here.

169
00:09:06,140 --> 00:09:09,580
Then you click on Create Disk,
and that's it.

170
00:09:09,580 --> 00:09:11,290
It burns a disk.

171
00:09:11,290 --> 00:09:14,260
You can write on to it,
system repair disk.

172
00:09:14,260 --> 00:09:18,820
In the event the PC can't boot up,
of course you have

173
00:09:18,820 --> 00:09:23,720
to change the boot order in your
BIOS to boot from a DVD first.

174
00:09:23,720 --> 00:09:25,970
Just put that into your DVD drive.

175
00:09:25,970 --> 00:09:26,780
Close that tray.

176
00:09:26,780 --> 00:09:29,280
